statement.tex:
%text Examine the continuity of $f(x)$ where $f(x)$ is defined as
% \[\qquad f(x) = \begin{cases} \sin x - \cos x,\, x\neq 0 \\ -1, \, x = 0 \end{cases} \]

options.tex: \textcolor{blue}{To Prove}\newline $f(x)$ is continuous \underline{for all $x$} -- including at $x = 10^4, 10^{99}$ etc.
\textcolor{blue}{To Prove}\newline $f(x)$ is continuous \underline{for $x$ in and around $0$}\newline -- but not at, say, $x = 10^4, 10^{99}$ etc.

reason.tex:
%text The question clearly asks to examine the \underline{continuity of $f(x)$}\newline
Which means \underline{for all $x$} - and not just some specific $x$. %

options.tex: %text $f(x) = \sin x-\cos x$ is continuous for all $x\neq 0$ %

reason.tex:
%text If two functions $a(x)$ and $b(x)$ are continuous in some domain, then so is $a(x) + b(x)$ and $a(x) - b(x)$\newline
Now, given that $\sin x$ and $\cos x$ are both continuous for $x\neq 0$, then so must $\sin x-\cos x$ be %

options.tex:
%text \[ \lim_{x\to 0} f(x) \neq f(0) \]
Hence, $f(x)$ is not continuous at $x = 0$ %

reason.tex:
\begin{align} \lim_{x\to 0} f(x) &= \lim_{x\to 0}(\sin x-\cos x) \\ &= 0 - 1 = -1 \\ \text{Also, } f(0) &= \sin 0 -\cos 0 = - 1 \\ \therefore \lim_{x\to 0} f(x) &= f(0)\implies\text{ continuity at }x=0 \end{align} %text
Hence, $f(x)$ is continuous for $x\neq 0$ and for $x= 0 \implies f(x)$ is continuous for all $x$
